guide.introduction: Here i'm going to show you how to use a cheap $10 MP3 Player, and have Arduino Control it.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Here i'm going to show you how to use a cheap $10 MP3 Player, and have Arduino Control it.

Relevant parts
  • Cheap MP3 Player
  • NPN Transistor
  • Project wire
Tools
  • Small Screw Driver
  • Soldering Iron, Wire strippers, solder

parts.notes: Not all MP3 Players will work... Try to get one without a screen.
Any Cheap ones from Radio Shack should work.
an old Cat5 Network Cable works great!

lines.text: Unscrew the two screws on the side and take off the white cover.
lines.text_raw: Unscrew the two screws on the side and take off the white cover.

lines.text: Push the circuit board with little force and it will come out on the other side.
lines.text_raw: Push the circuit board with little force and it will come out on the other side.

lines.text: The buttons are covered with a plastic sticker cover so just pull it off.
lines.text_raw: The buttons are covered with a plastic sticker cover so just pull it off.

lines.text: Solder thin wires to the buttons. Two wires per button, one wire on the inner plate & one wire on the outer plate.
lines.text_raw: Solder thin wires to the buttons. Two wires per button, one wire on the inner plate & one wire on the outer plate.

lines.text: A category 5 Network Cable works great for this! I used an old network cable I had laying around.
lines.text_raw: A category 5 Network Cable works great for this! I used an old network cable I had laying around.

lines.text: In the image I only connected the Play/Pause, Previous, and Next Buttons. You can do the same for the volume buttons if you wish.
lines.text_raw: In the image I only connected the Play/Pause, Previous, and Next Buttons. You can do the same for the volume buttons if you wish.

lines.text: Now I connected the MP3 Player to the Arduino using a NPN Transistor. The NPN Transistor acts like a switch. (You could also use relays if you don't have any transistors.)
lines.text_raw: Now I connected the MP3 Player to the Arduino using a NPN Transistor. The NPN Transistor acts like a switch. (You could also use relays if you don't have any transistors.)

lines.text: Wire the transister as follows:
lines.text_raw: Wire the transister as follows:

lines.text: Collector: Outer Plate on button.
lines.text_raw: Collector: Outer Plate on button.

lines.text: Base: to a 1k Resistor, then to the Arduino as shown in the next step.
lines.text_raw: Base: to a 1k Resistor, then to the Arduino as shown in the next step.

lines.text: Emitter: Using 2 wires, wire one to the Inner Plate on button, and the other to the Ground on the Arduino.
lines.text_raw: Emitter: Using 2 wires, wire one to the Inner Plate on button, and the other to the Ground on the Arduino.

lines.text: Remember the Resistors we connected to the "Base" pin on the transistors?
lines.text_raw: Remember the Resistors we connected to the "Base" pin on the transistors?

lines.text: We need to connect the other end of the resistors to the Arduino as follows:
lines.text_raw: We need to connect the other end of the resistors to the Arduino as follows:

lines.text: Play/Pause Button: Analog Pin 1
lines.text_raw: Play/Pause Button: Analog Pin 1

lines.text: Previous Button: Analog Pin 2
lines.text_raw: Previous Button: Analog Pin 2

lines.text: Next Button: Analog Pin 3
lines.text_raw: Next Button: Analog Pin 3

lines.text: Make sure that you have a spare USB Cable that will work with the MP3 player before doing this step.
lines.text_raw: Make sure that you have a spare USB Cable that will work with the MP3 player before doing this step.

lines.text: This wire is going to be used for charging the MP3 Player from the Arduino board.
lines.text_raw: This wire is going to be used for charging the MP3 Player from the Arduino board.

lines.text: (You can skip this step if you don't want the Arduino to automatically charge the MP3 Player)
lines.text_raw: (You can skip this step if you don't want the Arduino to automatically charge the MP3 Player)

lines.text: Take the USB Cable that came with the MP3 Player. Cut the end off that goes to the computer. We need the end that plugs into the MP3 Player.
lines.text_raw: Take the USB Cable that came with the MP3 Player. Cut the end off that goes to the computer. We need the end that plugs into the MP3 Player.

lines.text: There should be 4 wires inside of the cable. Use the red & black wires. (cut the other two off, as they are not needed)
lines.text_raw: There should be 4 wires inside of the cable. Use the red & black wires. (cut the other two off, as they are not needed)

lines.text: Now connect the Black Wire to the GND on your Arduino.
lines.text_raw: Now connect the Black Wire to the GND on your Arduino.

lines.text: And connect the Red Wire to the +5v on your Arduino.
lines.text_raw: And connect the Red Wire to the +5v on your Arduino.

lines.text: You don't have to connect pins to them. I did it because I'm using a connector.
lines.text_raw: You don't have to connect pins to them. I did it because I'm using a connector.

lines.text: This step is Optional
lines.text_raw: This step is Optional

lines.text: Solder wires to the Stereo Phone Plug. (You can get one of these at your local Radio Shack)
lines.text_raw: Solder wires to the Stereo Phone Plug. (You can get one of these at your local Radio Shack)

lines.text: There should be 3 wires.  Be sure to mark which one is the ground wire.
lines.text_raw: There should be 3 wires.  Be sure to mark which one is the ground wire.

lines.text: Now Solder the 3 wires to the speaker.
lines.text_raw: Now Solder the 3 wires to the speaker.

lines.text: If only using 1 speaker, connect the L & R Wires together to the Positive side of the speaker.  Connect the GND wire to the Negative side of the speaker.
lines.text_raw: If only using 1 speaker, connect the L & R Wires together to the Positive side of the speaker.  Connect the GND wire to the Negative side of the speaker.

lines.text: Now plug the jack into MP3 Player.
lines.text_raw: Now plug the jack into MP3 Player.

guide.summary: Use a cheap $10 MP3 Player, and control it using an Arduino.
